bestBHT.bht: The blind man's outcry to be brought to Jesus was a powerful and persistent one, with his clamorous cries surpassing mere shouts. Luke emphasizes the significance of bringing the sick to Christ, using terminology associated with bringing patients to a physician. Despite being rebuked, the blind man's unwavering plea for mercy echoed the importunity praised by Jesus in the Parable of the Persistent Widow. This story serves as a reminder for us to approach Jesus persistently, undeterred by the disapproval or discouragement of others.

Henry Alford: 39.] they which went before: in Matthew, “the multitude;” in Mark, “many.”
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: importunity so commended in the Syrophenician woman, and so
Marvin Vincent: Cried [εκραζεν] . A stronger word than ejbohsen, cried, in the previous verse, which is merely to cry or shout, while this is to cry clamorously; to scream or shriek."
To be brought unto [αχθηναι προς] . Used by Luke alone in the sense of bringing the sick to Christ."
He also uses the compound verb prsoagw, which was a common medical term for bringing the sick to a physician, both in that and in other senses.
Archibald T. Robertson: That he should hold his peace...That he should become silent."
John Gill: being not well pleased that he should call him the son of David, which was acknowledging him to be the Messiah
he cried so much the more, thou son of David, have mercy on me
so persons sensible of their need of Christ, and of his worth, excellency, and ability, are not to be discouraged from an application to him, by whatsoever they meet with from men, or devils.

bhtAttempts.bht: The blind man cried out clamorously to be brought to Christ, using a stronger word than simply shouting or crying. Luke emphasizes the importance of bringing the sick to Christ, using a medical term commonly associated with bringing patients to a physician. The blind man's persistence in crying out Thou Son of David, have mercy on me is commendable, as it is a demonstration of the same importunity that Jesus praised in the Parable of the Persistent Widow. Despite being rebuked by those around him, the blind man cried out even more loudly, undeterred by their disapproval. This story reminds us to constantly approach Jesus with our needs, not being discouraged or silenced by others.

The blind man's outcry to be brought to Jesus was a powerful and persistent one, with his clamorous cries surpassing mere shouts. Luke emphasizes the significance of bringing the sick to Christ, using terminology associated with bringing patients to a physician. Despite being rebuked, the blind man's unwavering plea for mercy echoed the importunity praised by Jesus in the Parable of the Persistent Widow. This story serves as a reminder for us to approach Jesus persistently, undeterred by the disapproval or discouragement of others.

The blind man's fervent cry to be brought to Jesus was not a mere shout, but a clamor that surpassed normal volume. Luke emphasizes the importance of bringing the sick to Christ using a term associated with bringing patients to a physician. Despite being rebuked, the blind man's persistent plea for mercy reflects the kind of importunity commended by Jesus in the Parable of the Persistent Widow. This story teaches us the value of approaching Jesus with unwavering persistence, undeterred by the disapproval of others.

The blind man's persistent cry to be brought to Jesus went beyond a mere shout, as he clamorously called out for help. Luke underscores the significance of bringing the sick to Christ, employing language commonly used in the medical field. Despite being rebuked, the blind man's unwavering plea for mercy demonstrated the kind of fervent persistence that Jesus praised in the Parable of the Persistent Widow. This account serves as a powerful reminder to approach Jesus with unyielding determination, regardless of the disapproval of others.

The blind man's impassioned cry to be brought to Jesus was not a mere shout, but a clamorous and desperate plea. Luke emphasizes the importance of bringing the sick to Christ, using language associated with medical terminology. Despite facing rebuke, the blind man's persistent cry for mercy reflected the same importunity praised in the Parable of the Persistent Widow. This story serves as a powerful reminder to approach Jesus with unwavering persistence, regardless of the disapproval or discouragement of others.
